title-group.article-title: Taxonomic Revision of Cirrodrilus makinoi (Annelida: Clitellata: Branchiobdellida) with a Redescription of C. homodontus

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Taxonomic Revision of
Cirrodrilus makinoi
(Annelida: Clitellata : Branchiobdellida ) with a Redescription of
C. homodontus
Akifumi Ohtaka 1,4,5 , Tomoaki Konno 2 , and Stuart R. Gelder 3

1
Faculty of Education, Hirosaki University, Hirosaki,
Aomori 036-8560, Japan E-mail: ohtaka@hirosaki-u
.ac. jp 2 Graduate School of Environmental Science , Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Hokkaido 060-0810, Japan 3 Department of Science , University of Maine at Presque Isle, Maine 04769, USA
4
Present address: Fujimidai, Hirosaki, Aomori 036-8143, Japan 5 Corresponding author
(Received 18 October 2023 ; Accepted 11 December 2023 )

Cirrodrilus makinoi
(
)
has not been identified since it was originally described from the Japanese crayfish,
Cambaroides japonicus (De Haan, 1841)
on Hokkaido Island , northern Japan
. A critical morphological comparison of the original and new material of
C. makinoi
with those of closely related
C. tsugarensis Gelder and Ohtaka, 2000
,

from Honshu Island, reveals there are no differentiating morphological character to separate the two species. A molecular study using the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I gene supports this view, therefore,
C. tsugarensis
becomes a subjective junior synonym of
C. makinoi .
Another species resembling
C. makinoi
,
C. homodontus
Yamaguchi , 1932 is confirmed to be a distinct species and both are redescribed based on the original and new material.

Key Words:
Cirrodrilus tsugarensis
, synonym , Japanese branchiobdellidans , COI gene , phylogenetic reconstruction .

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Branchiobdellidans on the only indigenous crayfish in Japan ,
Cambaroides japonicus (De Haan, 1841)
, have been studied by a number of authors (
,
,
;
, b, c, 1934, 1935a, b;
;
;
,
;
;
, 2023;
; Ohtaka et al. 2023), and 14 nominal species have been described under the genera
Branchiobdella Odier, 1823
,
Cirrodrilus Pierantoni, 1905
and
Stephanodrilus Pierantoni, 1906
.
Stephanodrilus
was subsequently recognized as a junior synonym of
Cirrodrilus
by
. Recently
B. digitata Pierantoni, 1906
, originally described from partially decomposed specimens in the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle (Paris), by
, was revised in a new combination,
C. digitatus
, and involved
C. inukaii
(
) becoming a junior synonym of the former (
). In addition,
C. ezoensis
(
) was also shown to be a junior synonym of
C. japonicus ( Pierantoni, 1912 )
, which was described based on similarly poorly preserved specimens from the Museum of Nature-Zoology, Hamburg (
). As a result, taxonomic diversity of indigenous branchiobdellidans on
Ca. japonicus
consists of 12 valid species all belonging to the genus
Cirrodrilus
.

The distribution of these species on either Hokkaido or northern Honshu Islands was based mainly on collection records associated with species descriptions
.
showed that nine species were distributed on Hokkaido Island :
C
. digitatus (as
C. inukaii
),
C. japonicus
(as
C. ezoensis
),
C. megalodentatus
(
),
C. homodontus
( Yamaguchi , 1932),
C. makinoi
(
),
C. sapporensis ( Pierantoni, 1906 )
,
C. nipponicus
( Yamaguchi , 1932),
C. uchidai
( Yamaguchi , 1932),
C. cirratus Pierantoni, 1905
, while one species,
C. aomorensis
(
) was obtained only from northern Honshu Island . Additionally, two species,
C. tsugarensis Gelder and Ohtaka, 2000
and
C. iwakiensis Ohtaka and Gelder, 2015
, were reported only from Honshu (
;
), and the faunal separation of species between Hokkaido and Honshu Islands was unaffected.

A recent intensive survey on the distribution of branchiobdellidans on
Ca. japonicus
in the Japanese Archipelago collected 11 of the 12 valid species of
Cirrodrilus
so far recorded (Ohtaka et al. 2023). The investigation did not identify any
C. makinoi
using the description made by
,
) or the key by
; however, a specimen from Hokkaido Island was ascribed to
C. tsugarensis
which closely resembled
C. makinoi
. This was unusual as
C. tsugarensis
had previously been reported only from Honshu Island (Ohtaka et al. 2023). This raised the possibility of
C. tsugarensis
and
C. makinoi
being a single species. To resolve this uncertainty, we conducted a careful review of the literature, a morphological re-examination of
C. makinoi
slide-mounted specimens in the late Professor Hideji Yamaguchi’s collection along with freshly collected specimens of
C. makinoi
and
C. tsugarensis
.
had noted
© 2024 The Japanese Society of Systematic Zoology.

This is an open access article distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License (CC BY, https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and a close relationship between
C. makinoi
and
C. homodontus
and this was investigated as well. The comparative morphological study was accompanied by an analysis of the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I gene in each of the three species to assess their phylogenetic closeness.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p:
Syntypes of
C. makinoi
were borrowed from the Invertebrate Collection of the Hokkaido University Museum, Sapporo, Japan (ICHUM) and re-examined morphologically. Newly collected specimens of
C. makinoi
identified according to
from Esashi (No. 8 in Fig. 1 ) and Samani (No. 9) on Hokkaido Island and those of
C. tsugarensis
from the original locality, Imabetsu (No. 6) on Honshu Island were also examined. In addition, a slide-mounted voucher specimen of
C. tsugarensis
from Jōzankei, Sapporo, Hokkaido (No. 7) (Ohtaka et al. 2023: 28, fig. 3A–C) was also examined, together with the voucher specimens of
C. homodontus
from the ICHUM collection and Ohtaka et al. (2023), and newly collected material.

Live branchiobdellidans recovered from
Ca. japonicus
were preserved in a 70% ethanol solution, material for microscopical examination was then dehydrated in ethanol, cleared in methyl salicylate, and mounted in Canada balsam on glass slides. Morphological examinations of whole-mounted specimens were conducted with research-level optical microscopes using bright-field, dark-field, phase contrast, and differential interference contrast (DIC) illuminations.

Molecular phylogenetic protocols: 12 of the specimens preserved in 70% ethanol were selected for molecular analysis with each individual being severed transversely through segment 7, 8, or 9. The anterior body was processed for slide mounting (see above) and deposited at the ICHUM, while the posterior portion was prepared for analyzing its cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COI) gene sequence. The 12 individuals ( Table 1 ) consisted of: 4—
C. tsugarensis
(1 from Sapporo , Hokkkaido ; 3 from Imabetsu , Honshu ); 2—
C. makinoi
( Esashi and Samani , Hokkaido ); and 6—
C. homodontus
(4 from Sapporo , 1 from Esashi, and 1 from Samani , Hokkaido ). The four specimens of
C. homodontus
from Sapporo were sympatric with one
C. tsugarensis
, and one
C. homodontus
was sympatric with one
C. makinoi
from Samani and a similar pair collected from Esashi .

Phylogenetic reconstruction of fragments of COI gene was performed using the maximum likelihood (ML) methods using MEGA11. Prior to running the analyses, the optimal model of nucleotide evolution for the ML was determined by Akaike information criterion and Bayesian information criterion using MEGA11. The T92 + G model was found as the best model. Phylogenetic trees were analyzed with 2000 bootstrap replicates using MEGA11. For an outgroup, we used the COI sequence of
B. italica Canegallo, 1928
(INSD accession number: KY775121). Evolutionary divergence between sequences was estimated using pairwise comparison of the uncorrected sequence divergences ( p -distances) and performed in MEGA11.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The suspicions that
C. makinoi
and
C. tsugarensis
were the same species has been demonstrated morphologically and supported by the COI sequences. Therefore,
C. tsugarensis
becomes a subjective junior synonym of
C. makinoi
. This taxonomic conclusion requires the morphological redescription of
C. makinoi
and an emended description of the sister species,
C. homodontus
. Confirmatory data is provided by the phylogenetic reconstruction of the COI gene.

sec.title: Taxonomic Accounts
sec.p:
Stephanodrilus makinoi
:
.

Type material.
did not designate any type specimens for
C. makinoi
. Six whole-mounted specimens identified in the ICHUM collection (
) were thus deemed to be syntypes for
C. makinoi
by
, but these slide-mounted specimens had no labels and the catalogue information is believed lost.
According to
, therefore, the type locality of this species can be determined as somewhere, i
.e.,
“Soranuma, Hattaribetsu, Shimofurano, Makomanai, Muroran, [or] Shintoku ,” in Hokkaido
.

Material examined. All six syntype specimens of
C
. makinoi mentioned above: ICHUM-1402, 1404–1406, 1408, 1409. ICHUM-8591, a whole-mounted specimen of
C. makinoi
from Samani , Hokkaido ( 42.11°N , 142.99°E ; No. 9 in Fig. 1 ),
2 October 2020
, coll . T . Konno. ICHUM-8592, a whole-mounted specimen of
C. makinoi
from Esashi , Hokkaido ( 45.05°N , 142.50°E ; No. 8),
18 October 2020
, coll . T . Konno. ICHUM-8593, a whole-mounted specimen of
C. tsugarensis
from Jōzankei , Sapporo , Hokkaido ( 42.96°N , 141.22°E ; No. 7),
31 August 2016
, coll . A
. Ohtaka and I
. Koizumi. ICHUM-8594–8596 and an additional 15 whole-mounted specimens from Imabetsu, Aomori Prefecture , where is the type locality of
C. tsugarensis
( 41.22°N , 140.56°E ; No. 6),
9 September 1997 , 14 November 1997 , 24 October 2010 , 28 October 2017
, coll . A . Ohtaka
. All the specimens were removed from
Ca
. japonicus.

Width of the dorsal and ventral jaws ranged from 26.0 µm to 29.0 µm (N = 8, mean value 27.1 µm) in the four syntype specimens of
C
. makinoi (ICHUM-1402, 1406, 1408, 1409).
Those in the newly collected specimens of
C
. makinoi from Samani and Esashi , Hokkaido ranged from 27.0 µm to 32.0 µm, those in the specimen of
C
. tsugarensis from Sapporo , Hokkaido , were 30.0 µm and 32.0 µm, and the 18 topotypes of
C
. tsugarensis from Imabetsu , Honshu , ranged from 23.0 µm to 35.0 µm (N = 35, mean value 27.9 µm)
.
drew a jaw and gave its magnification as ×440, and from the reprint fig. 10B in the work, its width was calculated, 34 µm wide.
Although the calculated jaw width in the original figure (
) is slightly larger than those measured in the syntypes and other specimens from Hokkaido and Honshu localities, the difference is not significant
.

Distribution.
reported under the name of
Stephanodrilus ( S. ) makinoi
(Nos 1–5 in Fig. 1 ) five localities on Hokkaido , while
and Ohtaka et al. (2023) recorded one each on Honshu (No. 6) and Hokkaido (No. 7) under the name of
C. tsugarensis .
Specimens used in the present study were collected from two additional localities on Hokkaido (Nos 8 and 9). In compiling these records,
C. makinoi
is shown to be widely distributed in Hokkaido along with an area on Honshu Island.

Host.
Cambaroides japonicus (De Haan, 1841)
, the “Japanese crayfish” or “Nihon-zarigani” in Japanese.
Habitat. Specimens have been observed alive on all parts of the exposed host’s surface.

Cambarincola homodonta
, fig. 1.

Stephanodrilus homodontus
:
.

Type material.
did not designate any type specimens but stated
C. homodontus
were collected from Soranuma , Hokkaido , Japan ( No. 10 in Fig. 1 ), which by definition becomes the type locality.
Later ,
reported the species from Soranume , Hattaribetsu , Shimofurano , Makomanai , Muroran and Shintoku, Hokkaido ( Nos 10, 11, 12, 3, 4, and 5, respectively)
.
Seven whole-mounted specimens were identified as
C
. homodontus in the ICHUM collection (
), but as the slides were unlabeled and catalogue information is believed lost, their actual origin remains unknown.
However , it is likely that at least some are syntypes but in the absence of firm data, the specimens were deemed to be potential syntypes by
. (2020).

Material examined. ICHUM-1837–1840, 1842, 1845, 1846, are all potential syntype specimens of
C. homodontus
.
ICHUM-8597–8600, four whole-mounted specimens from Jōzankei , Sapporo and one each from Samani (ICHUM-8601) and Esashi (ICHUM-8602): locations, dates and collector are the same as those given for the
C
. makinoi specimens described above.
Four whole-mounted specimens from Wakkanai , Hokkaido ( 45.43°N , 141.66°E ),
19 October 2020
, coll
. T . Konno
. One whole-mounted specimen from Yagishiri Island , Hokkaido ( 44.43°N , 141.41°E ),
28 August 2002
, coll
. T . Kawai
. Four whole-mounted specimens from Kaminokuni , Hokkaido ( 41.70°N , 140.27°E ),
20 August 2017
, coll
. A . Ohtaka
. All the specimens were removed from
Ca
. japonicus.

Variations. Peristomial tentacles in preserved specimens often become swollen or shortened and difficult to distinguish ( Fig. 5C, D ); often as a result of preservation and mounting conditions. The jaw width in 13 specimens , including Yamaguchi’s voucher and our newly collected ones ranged from 21.0 µm to 29.0 µm (N = 25, mean value 25.4 µm). The dental formula of 9/9 (4-1-4/4-1-4) varies slightly with two jaws having five small teeth on one side and three on the other side of the large median tooth, e.g.,
Distribution. Widely distributed across Hokkaido Island (open symbols in Fig. 1 ).

Host.
Cambaroides japonicus (De Haan, 1841)
, the “Japanese crayfish” or “Nihon-zarigani” in Japanese.
Habitat. Specimens have been observed alive on all parts of the exposed host’s surface.
Molecular phylogenetic analyses

The 588 bp COI sequences were obtained from four samples of
C. tsugarensis
(three from Imabetsu and one from Sapporo), and two samples of
C. makinoi
from Samani and Esashi, and six samples (four from Sapporo, one from Esashi and Samani) in
C. homodontus
. The ML tree is shown in Fig. 6 . The phylogenetic analysis showed that
C. makinoi
and
C. tsugarensis
are nested, while Hokkaido clade (Sapporo, Esashi, Samani) and Honshu clade (Imabetsu) can be recognized. The monophyly of the present specimens of
C. homodontus
was not supported, but they formed a lineage distinct to the clade consisting of Hokkaido and Honshu clades of
C. makinoi
/
tsugarensis
. The intra- and interspecific uncorrected p -distances calculated from the three sequences of the Hokkaido clade, three sequences of the Honshu clade of
C. makinoi
/
tsugarensis
, and six sequences of
C. homodontus
are summarized in Table 2 . The interspecific uncorrected p -distance between six sequences of
C. makinoi / tsugarensis
and six sequence of
C. homodontus
was calculated at 15.1% in average. In
C. makinoi
/
tsugarensis
, the Hokkaido clade differed from the Honshu clade by only 4.7% in average.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
In the original description of
C. tsugarensis , Gelder and Ohtaka (2000)
regarded the number and length of peristomial tentacles, and number of small teeth on the jaws as discriminating characters for separating the species from
C. makinoi .
Namely
C. tsugarensis
has five dorsal lip and three pairs of lateral tentacles of similar lengths, while in
C. makinoi
, the median tentacle on the dorsal lip is shorter than the adjacent two lateral pairs, and there are only two pairs of lateral tentacles; these being shorter than lateral dorsal tentacles.

According to
, peristomial tentacles are basically similar in length in
C. tsugarensis
, but as noted, a shorter median tentacle is a variation. Current observations found that the length of the dorsal lip median tentacle varied from being shorter to sub-equal to the lateral ones. This agrees with Yamaguchi’s syntypes of
C. makinoi
as well as in the topotypes of
C. tsugarensis .
described two pairs of lateral tentacles in the text of
C. makinoi
and a pair of lobes on each side of the ventral lip (
: fig. 10D).
interpreted these as a contracted third pair of lateral tentacles making the same arrangement as in
C. tsugarensis
. The length of the lateral tentacles are shorter in the original figure (
: fig. 10A), while they are subequal in length in
C. tsugarensis
(
: fig. 1B). The length and shape of peristomium tentacles, lobes, and other external body features in branchiobdellidans can vary due to a specimen’s reaction to preservation conditions (
;
;
). Common artifacts include tentacles contracting and peristomia curving inwardly on contact with the preservative, or tentacle and body elongation due to decomposition or when subjected to strong pressure during slide mounting. However, small variations in the peristomial tentacles and body dimensions are inevitable even during careful preservation and slide-mounting protocols. Taking these factors into consideration, differences in the number and form of peristomial tentacles between
C. makinoi
and
C. tsugarensis
were not found to be significant.

regarded that difference in the number of small teeth as an important character in discriminating
C. tsugarensis
from
C. makinoi
; a dental formula of 3-1-3/3- 1-3 in the former and 4-1-4/4- 1-4 in the latter. The present observation using 11 topotypes of
C. tsugarensis
showed that the 3-1-3 configuration was dominant, but six individuals possessed a 3-1-2 or 4- 1-3 in one of their jaws.
: fig. 10B) showed only one jaw with eight small teeth for
C. makinoi ,
but he stateded “Both plates are each provided with a large median tooth and six to eight small lateral ones”, denoting that the number of small teeth was variable. Current observations revealed the dental formula varies from 7/6 (3-1-3/2-1-3) to 9/9 (4-1-4/4-1-4) in the syntypes of
C. makinoi
. Therefore, these variations in the number of small teeth are not a taxonomically defining feature between
C. makinoi
and
C. tsugarensis
.

The location of the anterior pair of nephridial pores on the dorsal surface of segment 3 appear to be different in
C. makinoi
and
C. tsugarensis
. According to
, those in
C. makinoi
open near the midline, while the pores are located dorso-laterally to the midline in
C. tsugarensis ( Gelder and Ohtaka 2000 )
. Although this difference is significant in some species of
Cirrodrilus
, it is regarded as an intraspecific variation in this case. The reproductive organs in
C. makinoi
were not mentioned in
original description, and they could not be distinguished in any of the syntypes when examined. This phenomenon has been observed in other branchiobdellidans, where the preservative became too dilute on reaching the internal organs and allowed tissue decomposition to occur. However, these organs were described in specimens from Sapporo, Hokkaido , under the name
C. tsugarensis (Ohtaka et al. 2023)
. The glandular atrium is long consisting of a dilated ental half and a tubular ectal part. The spermatheca is also long with its muscular tube having a narrow ectal and then a dilated ental portion that connects with a club-shape spermathecal bulb.

noted that
C. makinoi
“quite resembles [ C. ]
homodontus
but is distinct in lobation of peristomium and position of the anterior nephridial pores”. The four dorsal tentacle and two pairs of lateral tentacles described in the original description (
) are confirmed in the present observations, and they are distinctly different from
C. makinoi
in which five dorsal lip and three pairs of lateral tentacles are present. In addition, the peristomium and peristomial tentacles are distinctly shorter in
C. homodontus
than in
C. makinoi
. In contrast, the dorsal and ventral jaws are similar in shape in both species, and their sizes are not significantly different. Unlike most species, the small teeth in
C. homodontus
and
C. makinoi
are not conical but have an angular ridge running from point to base, suggesting a close relationship. The dental formula in
C. homodontus
is 9/9 with a predominant small tooth configuration of 4-1-4, but with a slight variation of 5-1-3 or 3-1-5, while 3-1-3 was predominant in
C. makinoi
with variants of 3-1-2 and 4-1-4.

Our phylogenetic analysis indicates the conspecificity of
C. makinoi
and
C. tsugarensis
, and this supports their morphologically indistinguishability as a single species, while clearly
C. homodontus
is a distinct species. The uncorrected p -distance between
C. homodontus
and
C. makinoi / tsugarensis
was calculated at 15.1%, while within the
C. makinoi / tsugarensis
complex between the Hokkaido and Honshu clades, it was only 4.7%.
calculated uncorrected p -distances between sequences obtained in their study and COI sequences of the same species used in earlier studies in 16 species of North American branchiobdellidans. When sequence-determined errors caused in the field or laboratory were excluded, uncorrected p -distances obtained ranged 0.0–14.94% for nine species (
: table 4).
estimated uncorrected p -distance within species of European
Branchiobdella
determining average intraspecific p -distance values of 8.6% in
B. hexadonta Gruber, 1883
, 8.6% in
B. parasite (Braun, 1805)
, 4.6% in
B. italica
and 3.5% in
B. pentadonta Whitman, 1882
.

In our study, the p -distance value between Hokkaido and Honshu specimens was 4.7
%. Compared to the results of
and
,
uncorrected p -distance among all specimens analyzed in our study is smaller than values for the North American branchiobdellidans and
Branchiobdella species
.
Therefore , the three specimens from Hokkaido and the three from Honshu belong to the same species
. The original concern has been justified and confirmed that
C. tsugarensis
should become a subjective junior synonym of
C. makinoi
.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p:
The authors wish to thank Dr
. Tadashi Kawai for providing crayfish specimens from which branchiobdellidans used in this study were obtained.
We are grateful to Dr
. Itsuro Koizumi for financial support and the supporting molecular analysis.
Our appreciation is also extended to Dr
. Hiroshi Kajihara for the loan of the syntypes of
Cirrodrilus makinoi
and voucher specimens of
C. homodontus
from the late Professor Hideji Yamaguchi’s slide collection of branchiobdellidans deposited in the Invertebrate Collection of the Hokkaido University Museum , Sapporo , Japan .
We express our gratitude to Dr
. Takafumi Nakano and two anonymous reviewers for their comments that have improved the manuscript.

sec.title: Authors Contributions
sec.p: Akifumi Ohtaka: Conceptualization; Resources; Investigation; Formal Analysis; Writing – original draft; Writing – review & editing. Tomoaki Konno: Resources; Investigation; Formal Analysis; Writing – original draft. Stuart R. Gelder: Supervision; Writing – review & editing.

sec.title: Declarations
sec.p: Competing interests. The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
